com.neovisionaries.android.database

Class BaseCursor

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.database.CursorWrapper
      • com.neovisionaries.android.database.BaseCursor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.database.Cursor

    public class BaseCursor
extends android.database.CursorWrapper
    A cursor wrapper that provides some utility methods such as getXxxByName(String columnName).
    Since:
    1.3
    Author:
    Takahiko Kawasaki

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BaseCursor(android.database.Cursor cursor)
      Constructor that just calls super(cursor).

        Parameters:

        buffer - Destination buffer to copy data to.

      • getBlobByName

        public byte[] getBlobByName(String columnName)
        Get the value of the requested column as a byte array.

        This method is equivalent to getBlob(getColumnIndex(columnName)).

        Parameters:
        columnName - Column name.
        Returns:
        The value of the column.

      • isNullByName

        public boolean isNullByName(String columnName)
        Check if the value of the requested column is null.

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • getBoolean

        public boolean getBoolean(int columnIndex)
        Get the value of the requested column as a boolean.

        This method is equivalent to Boolean.valueOf(getString(columnIndex)).booleanValue().

        Parameters:
        columnIndex - Column index.
        Returns:
        The value of the column.

      • getBooleanByName

        public boolean getBooleanByName(String columnName)
        Get the value of the requested column as a boolean.

        This method is equivalent to getBoolean(getColumnIndex(columnName)).

        Parameters:
        columnName - Column name.
        Returns:
        The value of the column.

      • join

        public boolean join()
        Wait until this cursor finishes fetching data from the database.

        The specification allows data fetch to be performed asynchronously. As a matter of fact, the cursor implementation for SQLite may behave asynchronously. Asynchronous implementations of Cursor.getCount() return a negative value instead of 0 until they finish fetching data.

        Returns:
        True if this cursor finished data retrieval. False if the internal thread was interrupted for some reasons.
